title: The return of old-style Malay-centric politics?, East Asia Forum (Canberra), 25 April 2020, URL: https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2020/04/25/the-return-of-old-style-malay-centric-politics/
summary: As the world was gradually coming to terms with COVID-19, Malaysia was enveloped by a self-manufactured political crisis. Uncertainty prevailed over who wielded ultimate executive power in light of the abrupt resignation of Mahathir Mohamad. The Yang di-Pertuan Agong — Malaysia’s king — eventually settled on Muhyiddin Yassin as the best choice to lead the country as Malaysia’s eighth prime minister.

title: Podcast: Author Interview, "Schooling Diaspora"
summary:
In Schooling Diaspora: Women, Education, and the Overseas Chinese in British Malaya and Singapore, 1850s to 1960s (Oxford University Press, 2018), Karen Teoh relates the history of English and Chinese girls’ schools that overseas Chinese founded and attended from the 1850s to the 1960s in British Malaya and Singapore. She examines the strategies of missionaries, colonial authorities, and Chinese reformists and revolutionaries for educating girls, as well as the impact that this education had on identity formation among overseas Chinese women and larger society. These schools would help to produce what society ‘needed’, in the form of better wives and mothers, or workers and citizens of developing nation-states, while ensuring compliance with desired ideals. Chinese women in diaspora found that failing to conform to any number of state priorities could lead to social disapproval, marginalization, or even outright deportation.

Through vivid oral histories, and by bridging Chinese and Southeast Asian history, British imperialism, gender, and the history of education, Schooling Diaspora shows how these diasporic women contributed to the development of a new figure: the educated transnational Chinese woman.

title: Johor's capital Batu Sawar: Important Regional Trading Centre, c. 1590-1685
summary: What do we know about this forgotten capital of Johor from the 17th century? Surprisingly a lot. It was a Malay pepper port and home to a thriving trading community, carry trade and support industries. It featured regularly in geographies and glossaries of the late 17th and early 18th centuries. Arguably, Batu Sawar was better known in 18th century France, Austria, Germany and the Netherlands than in 21st Century Malaysia.

title: "Get Involved" magazine narrates Wonderful postgraduate students' life experiences at Universiti Putra Malaysia (UPM) and beyond in Malaysia, (Published by UPMISA Vol. 2, Issue 1, March 2014)
summary:
#PRAYFORMH370: Flight Tragedy with Global Search Record
Dear reader, let’s observe a minute of prayer for the crew and passengers of Malaysia Airline flight MH370 which mysteriously vanished into literally “the unknown” since 8th March, 2015.

After having many sleepless nights and hectic days putting things together for this edition of “Get Involved” magazine to go to press, suddenly a tragedy occurred. It was on the early hours of Saturday morning 8th March, 2014 when some 227 passengers with a 12-member crew of Malaysia Airlines (MAS) Boeing 777-200ER flight MH370, took off from Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) for Beijing, the Chinese capital. In just about an hour after taking off, the flight literally became invisible to the aviation radar, and mysteriously went missing. Malaysian Prime Minister Datuk Seri Mohamad Najib Tun Razak immediately solicited the support of about 26 countries including Australia, Britain, China, India, Indonesia, New Zealand, United Arab Emirates (UAE), United Kingdom (UK) and United States of America (USA). A sea and air convoy from those countries embarked on what has been so far the biggest search and rescue (SAR) operation in the history of aviation in the world. Huge resources which comprised not less than 22 aircraft, 6 helicopters and 19 ships have so far been mobilized by the good-Samaritan-countries to help the Malaysian Government in the search for the missing airliner. It’s now nearly one month since the SAR operations have been going on in the vast seas, oceans and continental Asia without any trace of MH370. Although Australian, Chinese, French and Thai satellites have lately picked pictures of images in the remotest parts of southern Indian Ocean thought to be debris of the missing aircraft, followed, lately by search for the flight data recorder popularly known as the black box, search is still going on inconclusively. 
Since the day the news of the tragic incidence was broken by the media, this tag: #PrayforMH370 or just #MH370 became one of the most trending hash tags on Twitter in Malaysia. Prayer sessions have been held by the Government and people of Malaysia for the recovery of the missing jet with 239 souls on board. Among about six nationals on the plane, about 152 of the passengers were Chinese with about a dozen of Malaysians, a few Americans and Indians, etc. 

The editorial board therefore wishes to, on behalf of the entire UPMISA officials and indeed the entire international students’ community of UPM, extends its sincere and heart-felt sympathy to the families and loved ones of the passengers and crew on board MAS flight MH370. We hope that, as painful as the situation is, they would be able to endure the tragedy with great fortitude and sense of responsibility while, at the same time, rendering their support to the Malaysian Government in its unrelenting efforts of searching for the whereabouts of the missing aircraft carrying their loved ones on board. We also wish to sympathize with the Malaysian Government and, by and large, the management of UPM over this sad incident. Please accept the highest assurances of our humble selves in sharing with you the pains and grief of this mysterious tragedy while we keep the flames of the candles of hope burning.

title: Di Sebalik Perjanjian Kemerdekaan
summary:
Kemerdekaan bagi setiap orang bererti kebebasan, tidak ditindas dari segala segi samada fizikal atau pun mental serta berhak mentadbir negara bangsanya sendiri tanpa campur tangan asing. Hakikatnya adakah kemerdekaan negara ini di dapati dengan mudah?. Ini adalah satu persoalan yang selalu bermain di setiap fikiran rakyat negara ini khasnya orang-orang Melayu. Bagi generasi kini kemerdekaan mungkin hanya di sambut dengan perarakan dan suka ria walaupun sebilangannya pula merasai apa itu pengorbanan untuk mencapai kemerdekaan. 

Setiap kaum di negara ini mempunyai penceritaan mereka yang tersendiri. Bagi mereka kemerdekaan yang di capai adalah atas usaha kaum masing-masing walaupun di atas lembaran sejarah apa yang di tulis ialah maksud kemerdekaan itu mestilah bersama dengan kaum lain di negara ini. Semuanya adalah hasil perancangan British sebagai kuasa yang mengurus Tanah Melayu pada waktu itu. Namun begitu apakah benar bahawa kemerdekaan yang kita capai ini tidak mengorbankan apa-apa?, apakah benar pengorbanan itu hanya melalui darah dan keringat?. Inilah persoalan yang sering difikirkan dan kadangkala merimaskan kita. Sejarah tidak pernah menipu walaupun cuba dikuburkan. Sejarah tidak pernah lupa kepada apa yang pernah di lalui oleh setiap warga negara ini terutama sekali orang Melayu. Hakikat yang sebenar dan tidak boleh dilindungi serta harus dikongsi kepada generasi hari ini ialah sesungguhnya orang-orang Melayu melalui kepimpinan terdahulu telah pun dikorbankan tanpa sedar atau tidak sengaja. Jika di telusuri sejarah kemerdekaan negara ini, kita pasti tidak boleh melepaskan peristiwa Malayan Union yang berlaku pada tahun 1946 dan kesan daripada kisah ini telah melahirkan satu semangat kebangsaan bagi seluruh orang Melayu pada waktu itu. British juga tidak menyangka bahawa orang-orang Melayu akan menentang akan usaha yang mereka lakukan. Hasilnya Akta Kerakyatan 1948 yang turut dikenali sebagai Perlembagaan Rakyat dilancarkan oleh AMCJA dan PUTERA. Pada ketika inilah Tan Cheng Lock yang memimpin AMCJA telah mencadangkan agar sebuah negara ditubuhkan dengan menyatukan seluruh Negeri Melayu dan Negeri Selat. Maka hasilnya lahirlah Persekutuan Tanah Melayu. Pada waktu ini jugalah beliau mencadangkan agar kerakyatan diberi kepada setiap bukan Melayu khasnya kaum Cina. Prinsip utama kerakyatan ini adalah berdasarkan prinsip jus soli yang sebenarnya merupakan perkara sama yang pernah diusulkan di dalam Malayan Union namun yang berbezanya ialah PUTERA telah mencadangkan agar semua kaum selepas kemerdekaan dinamakan sebagai bangsa Melayu. Hal ini telah mendapat tentangan daripada pelbagai pihak termasuk British, AMCJA dan UMNO. (Low Choo Chin:2013: hlm 64-70). Selepas PUTERA diharamkan oleh Kerajaan British Tanah Melayu pada tahun 1949, MCA ditubuhkan dan mula berbaik-baik dengan UMNO dengan alasan untuk bersama-sama memperjuangkan kemerdekaan seperti mana yang dimahukan British iaitu kerjasama di antara semua kaum (Ramlah Adam:2006:hlm6). Walaupun begitu perjuangan untuk mendapatkan kerakyatan Tanah Melayu tetap diteruskan melalui MCA. title: Islam, Political Culture and Practical Spirituality in Kedah, a State in Northwestern Malaysia, in Ananta Kumar Giri (ed.), Practical Spirituality and Human Development: Creative Experiments for Alternative Futures (Singapore: Palgrave Macmillan, 2019), pp. 323–352.
summary: Kedah, a state located in northwestern Peninsular Malaysia, may easily lay claim to be among the oldest civilisations of the Malay Archipelago. Kedah’s historical importance is distinguished by its widely acknowledged position as a thriving international port and trading mecca. The Islamisation of the Kedah monarchy in 1136 prepared the avenue for the large-scale dissemination of Islam covering the entire state. With the expansion of Islam in Kedah to encompass aspects of governance, a syncretic culture which combined Islamic with feudal elements emerged. From the overview of the history of Islam in Kedah, it is shown that Islam enjoys a symbiotic relationship with the culture that has fundamentally moulded the power dynamics of political praxis in Kedah. The relevant politico-cultural practitioners here include the kings and their family members, the royal inner circle, palace advisors, ruling elites, the ulama and modern politicians. From the point when Islam established itself as the most important factor in Kedah politics, the commanding heights of Kedah’s political equation were controlled by those who gave priority to tolerant practices such as negotiations, discussions, compromises, consensus and consociationalism.

title: Za'ba Memorial Library, University of Malaya
summary: My research blog documents my experience as a researcher in Za'ba Memorial Library, located in the University of Malaya in Kuala Lumpur. I demonstrate that this is a crucial archive for sources on the Malay scholar and Malaysia's father of the modern Malay language, Zainal Abidin bin Ahmad (Za'ba). I also highlight that this library may provide crucial references not only on Za'ba, but also on the economic life of Malaysia and the surrounding regions during the colonial and post colonial periods. This research blog is part of the Harvard-Cambridge Centre for History and Economics project called "Archives of Economic Life in South Asia." For Link to blog: https://www.histecon.magd.cam.ac.uk/archives-asia/blogs/wong2.html

title: Arkib Negara Malaysia (The Malaysia National Archives), Kuala Lumpur
summary: Part of the Harvard-Cambridge Centre for History and Economics project called "Archives of Economic Life in South Asia," my research blog documents my experience as a researcher in Arkib Negara Malaysia (The Malaysia National Archives) in Kuala Lumpur. I also discuss how their collections provide crucial references on the economic life of Malaysia and its surrounding regions, from a local and colonial perspective. For link to blog: https://www.histecon.magd.cam.ac.uk/archives-asia/blogs/wong.html
